results.title: Witness [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Edward S. Feldman and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Peter Weir’s captivating American film debut is presented as a white knuckle mystery thriller, collision of cultures and a sensual romance. An Amish boy witnesses a drug-related murder and with his mother (Kelly McGillis) and a wounded cop (Harrison Ford), takes refuge in the sheltered Amish community. Violence comes to “peacelands” in a film of stark contrasts, delicate subtleties and surprising humour. Note how the widow blooms under the cop’s attentions. Ford has never been better, portraying a hero real enough to show fear when faced with both barrels of a shotgun. Cast includes Josef Sommer, Lukas Haas, Jan Rubes, Alexander Godunov, Patti Lupone, Danny Glover and Brent Jennings.

results.title: Greece: North and South; Athens
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel, Travel”.
This travel video begins in the Halkidiki region of northern Greece, site of centuries-old monasteries. From Halkidiki we move to the city of Thessaloniki which is full of the influence of not only Greek and Roman civilisation but also Venetian and Arab. The travels continue south to the coastal regions of the Pelyponnese. In the second part we explore Athens: including the taverns of Plaka, the flea markets in Monasteraki, the original Olympic Stadium and , of-course, the Parthenon and the Acropolis.

results.title: The Arrested moment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Painter’s world: changing constants of art from the Renaissance to the present”.
This program explores how painters have achieved movement in a still image and have told stories in a single frame. Before photography, it did not occur to artists to isolate single moments. Medieval art saw the eternal moment, but with Renaissance art action became central. The program looks at how Michelangelo, Raphael, Titian, Leonardo and Caravaggio treated movement and then moves to the post-photography era and the works of Muybridge, Hockney, Duchamp and Pollock.

results.title: With Yau Kai in Hong Kong
results.creator_credit: Gail Singer, David Springbett, Heather MacAndrew and Asterisk Film and Videotape Productions
results.brief_description: Takes a look at the life style of a 14 year old boy who lives in on a sampan in one of the harbours near Hong Kong. Highlights aspect of commerce and trade in the area and the intrusion of Western values in a traditional life style.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gail Singer, David Springbett, Heather MacAndrew and Asterisk Film and Videotape Productions

results.title: What is PKU?
results.creator_credit: Deptartment of Audio Visual Communications, Glaxo Australia
results.brief_description: PKU is an accumulation of phenylalanine in the blood, which if left unchecked, will cause intellectual disability. Stresses the importance of diet in controlling this disorder.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Deptartment of Audio Visual Communications, Glaxo Australia

results.title: What is a word processor? or Tale of two sisters
results.creator_credit: Peter Robinson, Robert Reid, IBM (UK) and Video Arts
results.brief_description: A John Cleese training film which explains the principles and illustrates the nature of word processing. Shows all the aspects of office work which the processor can make quicker or easier, and provides a framework of understanding which dispels the mystery and threat surrounding this technology. Features John Cleese, Alison Steadman, Kay Stonham and Carol Hawkins. Photography by Arthur Wooster, sound by Bruce White, edited by Colin Sherman, narrated by Judi Dench, written by David Nobbs.

results.title: What is a Jew to you?
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Michael Rubetzki and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Documentary film maker Aviva Ziegler turns the camera on herself in this personal exploration of what being Jewish means to her and why she calls herself a Jew despite not maintaining a Jewish lifestyle. She speaks with family and friends about growing up in Sydney, commenting on religious practices from the past, pondering why her brother has maintained his Jewish heritage and Aviva has gravitated towards other groups in society. Aviva reaches the conclusion that the effects of the Holocaust have made her feel Jewish, regardless of whether she is living within the tradition or not.
